720730f-a.text:
84, 76-68 King Street, west of, adioining, and at the S.W. corner of Varick Street. The clearing in the foreground is part of the future site of the new United States Appraisers' Stores, a 1arge
building filling the entire block.
No. 84 King Street is a garage, built since 1921, and replacing
five old houses, Nos. 82 to 90 King Street.
December 7, 1927.
P. L. Sperr.
720730f-a.folder: King Street & Varick Street, Manhattan, NY

723764f-a.text:
Graphic Arts Building, Varick Street, east side, from King to Houston Streets, seen across the excavation on the west side for the United States Appraisers Stores Building.
December 7, 1927.
P. L. Sperr.
723764f-a.folder: Varick Street & King Street, Manhattan, NY

723766f-a.text:
Ecavation on the west side of Varick Street, from King to Houston (formerly Hamnersley) Streets. The entire block, from Varick to Huudson Streets, has been demolished for a new United States Appraiser's Stores Building. Across this clearing may be seen the old houses
on the west side of Hudson Street, Nos. 363 to 385.
December 7, 1927.
P. L. Sperr.
723766f-a.folder: Varick Street & King Street, Manhattan, NY

723765f-a.text:
Varick Street, west side, from King to Clarkson Streets, inclusive, showing the new Maltz Building and the clearing on which the new United States Appraiser's Stores is being built.
February 12, 1928.
P. L. Sperr.
723765f-a.folder: Varick Street & King Street, Manhattan, NY

720727f-a.text:
29 King Street, North Side, between Varick and Avenue of the Americas showing P.S. 8, built in 1886.
Board of Education, N.Y.C.
Neg. ~233
720727f-a.folder: King Street & Varick Street, Manhattan, NY

720729f-a.text:
King Street, north side, east from and including No. 49, east of Varick Street. Public School No. 8 occupies Nos. 35-27, inclusive. The eastern end of King Street is at MacDougal Street, between Houston and Prince Streets.
King Street was originally laid out as Hazard Street; it took its present name in 1807, after an officer in the Revolutionary War, not after His Majesty George III.
May 19, 1933.
P. L. Sperr.
720729f-a.folder: King Street & Varick Street, Manhattan, NY

720728f-a.text:
44, 46, 48 to 54 King Street, south side, east of and towards Varick Street. No. 46, the house with the dormer windows, is a frame building faced with brick. In the center of the double house 48-50 is a carriage underpass to the rear of the building. Adjoining No. 54 may be seen part of the Greybar-Varick Building (1930), which replaced Nos. 56-58 and 60 King Street.
September, 1935.
dift of R. W. Hill.
720728f-a.folder: King Street & Varick Street, Manhattan, NY
